entry.title: Reading Comprehension Section A (1) - English
entry.content:
ä¸€ã€é¢˜ç›®

2019å¹´12æœˆå››çº§çœŸé¢˜(ç¬¬3å¥—)-åäº”é€‰å

Millions of people travel by plane every single day. If youâ€™re planning on being one of them soon, you might not be looking forward to the 26 feeling air travel often leaves you with.

Besides the airport crowds and stress, travelling at a high altitude has real effects on the body. Although the pressure of the cabin is 27 to prevent altitude sickness, you could still 28 sleepiness or a headache. The lower oxygen pressure found in an aircraft cabin is 29 to that at 6,000-8,000 feet of altitude. A drop in oxygen pressure can cause headaches in certain 30 .To help prevent headaches, drink plenty of water, and avoid alcohol and coffee.

Airplane food might not really be as tasteless as you 31 thought. The air you breathe in a plane dries out your mouth and nose, which can affect your sense of taste. Perception of sweet and salty foods dropped by almost 30 percent in a simulation of air travel. However,you can make your taste buds active again by drinking water. A dry mouth may 32 taste sensitivity, but taste is restored by drinking fluids.

Although in-flight infections 33 in dry environments like airplanesï¼Œyour risk of getting sick from an airplane is actually low because of the air 34 used. Unless youâ€™re sitting next to someone who is coughing or sneezing, you shouldnâ€™t worry too much about getting sick. However, bacteria have been shown to live on cabin surfaces, so wash your hands 35.

é™¤äº†æœºåœºæ‹¥æŒ¤å’Œå‹åŠ›å¤–ï¼Œåœ¨é«˜ç©ºæ—…è¡Œå¯¹èº«ä½“ä¹Ÿæœ‰çœŸæ­£çš„å½±å“ã€‚

Although the pressure of the cabin is adjusted to prevent altitude sickness, you could still experience sleepiness or a headache.

å°½ç®¡æœºèˆ±çš„å‹åŠ›è¢«è°ƒæ•´ä»¥é˜²æ­¢é«˜åŸååº”ï¼Œä½†ä½ ä»ç„¶ä¼šæ„Ÿåˆ°å›°å€¦æˆ–å¤´ç—›ã€‚

The lower oxygen pressure found in an aircraft cabin is equivalent to that at 6,000-8,000 feet of altitude.

é£æœºå®¢èˆ±ä¸­å‘ç°çš„è¾ƒä½æ°§æ°”å‹åŠ›ç›¸å½“äºæµ·æ‹”6000-8000è‹±å°ºçš„æ°§æ°”å‹åŠ›ã€‚

A drop in oxygen pressure can cause headaches in certain individuals.

To help prevent headaches, drink plenty of water, and avoid alcohol and coffee.

Perception of sweet and salty foods dropped by almost 30 percent in a simulation of air travel.

åœ¨ä¸€é¡¹èˆªç©ºæ—…è¡Œæ¨¡æ‹Ÿä¸­ï¼Œäººä»¬å¯¹ç”œå’Œå’¸é£Ÿç‰©çš„è®¤çŸ¥ä¸‹é™äº†è¿‘30%ã€‚

entry.title: Match the question Section B (1) - English
entry.content:
ä¸€ã€é¢˜ç›®

2019å¹´12æœˆå››çº§çœŸé¢˜(ç¬¬3å¥—)-åŒ¹é…é¢˜

A South Korean city designed for the future takes on a life of its own

[A]Getting around a city is one thingâ€”and then thereâ€™s the matter of getting from one city to another. One vision of the perfect city of the future is a place that offers easy access to air travel. In 2011, a University of North Carolina business professor named John Kasarda published a book called Aerotropolis: The Way We â€˜ll Live Next. Kasarda says future cities should be built intentionally around or near airports. The ideaï¼Œ as he has put it, is to offer businesses â€œrapid, long-distance connectivity on a massive scale.â€

[B]â€The 18th century really was a waterborne(æ°´è¿çš„)century, the 19th century a rail century , the 20th century a highway, car, truck centuryâ€”and the 21 st century will increasingly be an aviation century , as the globe becomes increasingly connected by air,â€ Kasarda says. Songdo, a city built from scratch in South Korea, is one of Kasardaâ€™s prime examples. It has existed for just a few years. â€œFrom the outset, it was designed on the basis of connectivity and competitiveness,â€says Kasarda.â€The government built the bridge directly from the airport to the Songdo International Business District. And the surface infrastructure was built at the same time as the new airport.â€

[C]Songdo is a stoneâ€™s throw from South Koreaâ€™s Incheon Airport, its main international hub(æ¢çº½). But it takes a lot more than a nearby airport to be a city of the future. Just building a place as anâ€œinternational business districtâ€doesnâ€™t mean it will become one. Park Yeon Soo conceived(æ„æƒ³)this city of the future back in 1986. He considers Songdo his baby. Park sees himself as a visionary. Thirty years after he imagined the cityï¼ŒParkâ€™s baby is close to 70 percent built, with 36,000 people living in the business district and 90,000 residents in greater Songdo. Itâ€™s about an hour outside Seoul, built on former tidal flats along the Yellow Sea. Thereâ€™s a Coast Guard building and a tall trade tower, as well as a park, golf course and university.

[D]Chances are youâ€™ve actually seen this place. Songdo appears in the most famous music video ever to come out of South Korea.â€ Gangnam Styleâ€refers to the fashionable Gangnam district in Seoul. But some of the video was filmed in Songdo. â€œl donâ€™t know if you remember , there was a scene in a subway station.That was not Gangnam. That was actually Songdo,â€says Jung Won Son, a professor of urban development at London â€˜s Bartlett School of Planning. â€œPart of the reason to shoot there is that itâ€™s new and nice.â€

[E]The city was supposed to be a hub for global companies, with employees from all over the world. But thatâ€™s not how it has turned out. Songdoâ€™s reputation is as a futuristic ghost town. But the reality is more complicated.A bridge with big, light-blue loops leads into the business district. In the center of the main road, there â€˜s a long line of flags of the world.On the corner, thereâ€™s a Starbucks and a 7-Elevenâ€”all of the international brands that you see all over the world nowadays.

[F]The city is not empty. There are mothers pushing baby carriages, old women with walkersâ€”even in the middle of the day, when it â€˜s 90 degrees out. Byun Young-Jin chairs the Songdo real estate association and started selling property here when the first phase of the city opened in 2005. He says demand has boomed in.the past couple of years. Most of his clients are Korean. In fact, the developer says,99 percent of the homes here are sold to Koreans. Young families move here because the schools are great. And thatâ€™s the problem: Songdo has become a popular Korean cityâ€”more popular as a residential area than a business one. Itâ€™s not yet the futuristic international business hub that planners imagined.â€œ ltâ€™s a great place to live. And itâ€™s becoming a great place to work,â€says Scott Summers, vice president of Gale International , the developer of the city. The floor-to-ceiling windows of his companyâ€™s offices overlook Songdo Central Park, with a canal full of small boats and people fishing. Shimmering(é—ªçƒçš„)glass towers line the canalâ€™s edge.

[G]â€œWhat â€˜s happened is that our focus on creating that quality of life first has enabled the residents to live here,â€Summers says. But there needs to be strong economic incentives for companies to locate here. The city is still unfinished, and it feels a bit like a theme park. It doesnâ€™t feel all that futuristic. Thereâ€™s a high-tech underground trash disposal system. Buildings are environmentally friendly. Everybodyâ€™s television set is connected to a system that streams personalized language or exercise classes.

[H] But this is not Star Trek. And to some of the residentsï¼ŒSongdo feels hollow. â€œIâ€™m, like, in prison for weekdays. Thatâ€™s what we call it in the workplace,â€ says a woman in her 20s. She doesnâ€™t want to use her name for fear of being fired from her job. She goes back to Seoul every weekend.â€l say Iâ€™m prison-breaking on Friday nights.â€ But she has to make the prison break in her own car. Thereâ€™s no high-speed train connecting Songdo to Seoul, just over 20 miles away.

[I]Park Yeon Soo, the man who first imagined Songdo, feels frustrated, too. He says he built South Korea a luxury vehicle,â€like Mercedes or BMW. It â€˜s a good car now. But weâ€™re waiting for a good driver to accelerate.â€But there are lots of other good cars out there, too. The world is dotted with futuristic, high-tech cities trying to attract the biggest international companies.

[J]Songdoâ€™s backers contend that itâ€™s still early, and business space is filling upâ€”about 70 percent of finished offices are now occupied. Brent Ryanï¼Œwho teaches urban design at MIT,says Songdo proves a universal principle. â€œThere have been a lot of utopian(ä¹Œæ‰˜é‚¦çš„)cities in history. And the reason we don â€˜t know about a lot of them is that they have vanished entirely.â€ In other words, when it comes to citiesâ€”or anything elseâ€”it is hard to predict the future.

  1. Songdoâ€™s popularity lies more in its quality of life than its business attraction.

  2. The man who conceived Songdo feels disappointed because it has fallen short of his expectations.

  3. A scene in a popular South Korean music video was shot in Songdo.

  4. Songdo still lacks the financial stimulus for businesses to set up shop there.

  5. Airplanes will increasingly become the chief means of transportation, according to a professor.

  6. Songdo has ended up different from the city it was supposed to be.

  7. Some of the people who work in Songdo complain about boredom in the workplace.

  8. A business professor says that a future city should have easy access to international transportation.

  9. According to an urban design professor, it is difficult for city designers to foresee what will happen in the future.

  10. Park Yeon Soo, who envisioned Songdo, feels a parental connection with the city.

In fact, the developer says,99 percent of the homes here are sold to Koreans.

äº‹å®ä¸Šï¼Œå¼€å‘å•†è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œè¿™é‡Œ99%çš„æˆ¿å­éƒ½å–ç»™äº†éŸ©å›½äººã€‚

Young families move here because the schools are great.

å¹´è½»çš„å®¶åº­æ¬åˆ°è¿™é‡Œæ˜¯å› ä¸ºå­¦æ ¡å¾ˆæ£’ã€‚

And thatâ€™s the problem: Songdo has become a popular Korean cityâ€”more popular as a residential area than a business one.

è¿™å°±æ˜¯é—®é¢˜æ‰€åœ¨ï¼šæ¾å²›å·²ç»æˆä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªå—æ¬¢è¿çš„éŸ©å›½åŸå¸‚ï¼Œä½œä¸ºä½å®…åŒºæ¯”å•†ä¸šåŒºæ›´å—æ¬¢è¿ã€‚

Itâ€™s not yet the futuristic international business hub that planners imagined.

å®ƒè¿˜ä¸æ˜¯è§„åˆ’è€…æƒ³è±¡ä¸­çš„æœªæ¥å›½é™…å•†ä¸šä¸­å¿ƒã€‚

â€œltâ€™s a great place to live. And itâ€™s becoming a great place to work.â€says Scott Summers, vice president of Gale International , the developer of the city.

â€œè¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªéå¸¸é€‚åˆå±…ä½çš„åœ°æ–¹ã€‚å®ƒæ­£åœ¨æˆä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªéå¸¸å¥½çš„å·¥ä½œåœºæ‰€ã€‚â€åŸå¸‚å¼€å‘å•†Gale Internationalçš„å‰¯æ€»è£æ–¯ç§‘ç‰¹Â·è¨é»˜æ–¯ï¼ˆScott Summersï¼‰è¯´ã€‚

The floor-to-ceiling windows of his companyâ€™s offices overlook Songdo Central Park, with a canal full of small boats and people fishing.

ä»–çš„å…¬å¸åŠå…¬å®¤çš„è½åœ°çª—ä¿¯ç°ç€æ¾å²›ä¸­å¤®å…¬å›­ï¼Œè¿æ²³é‡Œæ»¡æ˜¯å°èˆ¹å’Œé’“é±¼çš„äººã€‚

Shimmering(é—ªçƒçš„)glass towers line the canalâ€™s edge.

é—ªé—ªå‘å…‰(é—ªçƒçš„)è¿æ²³è¾¹ç¼˜æœ‰ç»ç’ƒå¡”ã€‚

[G]

â€œWhatâ€™s happened is that our focus on creating that quality of life first has enabled the residents to live here,â€Summers says.

è¨é»˜æ–¯è¯´ï¼šâ€œæ‰€å‘ç”Ÿçš„äº‹æƒ…æ˜¯ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸“æ³¨äºé¦–å…ˆåˆ›é€ ç”Ÿæ´»è´¨é‡ï¼Œä½¿å±…æ°‘èƒ½å¤Ÿä½åœ¨è¿™é‡Œã€‚â€ã€‚

But there needs to be strong economic incentives for companies to locate here.

ä½†éœ€è¦æœ‰å¼ºæœ‰åŠ›çš„ç»æµæ¿€åŠ±æªæ–½ï¼Œè®©å…¬å¸åœ¨è¿™é‡Œå®‰å®¶è½æˆ·ã€‚

The city is still unfinished, and it feels a bit like a theme park.

è¿™åº§åŸå¸‚è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰å®Œå·¥ï¼Œæ„Ÿè§‰æœ‰ç‚¹åƒä¸€ä¸ªä¸»é¢˜å…¬å›­ã€‚

It doesnâ€™t feel all that futuristic.

æ„Ÿè§‰æ²¡æœ‰é‚£ä¹ˆæœªæ¥æ„Ÿã€‚

Thereâ€™s a high-tech underground trash disposal system.

æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªé«˜ç§‘æŠ€çš„åœ°ä¸‹åƒåœ¾å¤„ç†ç³»ç»Ÿã€‚

Buildings are environmentally friendly.

å»ºç­‘æ˜¯ç¯ä¿çš„ã€‚

Everybodyâ€™s television set is connected to a system that streams personalized language or exercise classes.

æ¯ä¸ªäººçš„ç”µè§†æœºéƒ½è¿æ¥åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªç³»ç»Ÿï¼Œè¯¥ç³»ç»Ÿå¯ä»¥æ’­æ”¾ä¸ªæ€§åŒ–çš„è¯­è¨€æˆ–é”»ç‚¼è¯¾ç¨‹ã€‚

[H]

But this is not Star Trek.

ä½†è¿™ä¸æ˜¯ã€Šæ˜Ÿé™…è¿·èˆªã€‹ã€‚

And to some of the residentsï¼ŒSongdo feels hollow.

å¯¹ä¸€äº›å±…æ°‘æ¥è¯´ï¼Œæ¾å¤šæ„Ÿåˆ°ç©ºè™šã€‚

â€œIâ€™m, like, in prison for weekdays. Thatâ€™s what we call it in the workplace,â€ says a woman in her 20s.

ä¸€ä½20å¤šå²çš„å¥³æ€§è¯´ï¼šâ€œæˆ‘å¹³æ—¥éƒ½åœ¨ç›‘ç‹±é‡Œã€‚è¿™å°±æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨å·¥ä½œåœºæ‰€æ‰€è¯´çš„ã€‚â€ã€‚

She doesnâ€™t want to use her name for fear of being fired from her job.

å¥¹ä¸æƒ³ä½¿ç”¨è‡ªå·±çš„åå­—ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæ‹…å¿ƒè¢«è§£é›‡ã€‚

She goes back to Seoul every weekend.

å¥¹æ¯ä¸ªå‘¨æœ«éƒ½å›é¦–å°”ã€‚

â€œl say Iâ€™m prison-breaking on Friday nights.â€

â€œæˆ‘è¯´æˆ‘æ˜ŸæœŸäº”æ™šä¸Šè¦è¶Šç‹±ã€‚â€

But she has to make the prison break in her own car.

ä½†å¥¹å¿…é¡»ç”¨è‡ªå·±çš„è½¦è¶Šç‹±ã€‚

Thereâ€™s no high-speed train connecting Songdo to Seoul, just over 20 miles away.

æ¾å²›å’Œé¦–å°”ä¹‹é—´æ²¡æœ‰é«˜é€Ÿåˆ—è½¦ï¼Œåªæœ‰20å¤šè‹±é‡Œè¿œã€‚

[I]

Park Yeon Soo, the man who first imagined Songdo, feels frustrated, too.

æœ´å»¶æ´™ï¼ˆPark Yeon Sooï¼‰ï¼Œç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæƒ³è±¡æ¾å²›çš„äººï¼Œä¹Ÿæ„Ÿåˆ°æ²®ä¸§ã€‚

He says he built South Korea a luxury vehicle,â€like Mercedes or BMW. It â€˜s a good car now. But weâ€™re waiting for a good driver to accelerate.â€

ä»–è¯´ï¼Œä»–åœ¨éŸ©å›½åˆ¶é€ äº†ä¸€è¾†è±ªåè½¦ï¼Œâ€œå°±åƒå¥”é©°æˆ–å®é©¬ã€‚ç°åœ¨è¿™è¾†è½¦å¾ˆå¥½ã€‚ä½†æˆ‘ä»¬æ­£åœ¨ç­‰å¾…ä¸€ä½å¥½å¸æœºåŠ é€Ÿã€‚â€

But there are lots of other good cars out there, too. The world is dotted with futuristic, high-tech cities trying to attract the biggest international companies.

ä½†ä¹Ÿæœ‰å¾ˆå¤šå…¶ä»–çš„å¥½è½¦ã€‚ä¸–ç•Œä¸Šåˆ°å¤„éƒ½æ˜¯æœªæ¥ä¸»ä¹‰çš„é«˜ç§‘æŠ€åŸå¸‚ï¼Œè¯•å›¾å¸å¼•æœ€å¤§çš„å›½é™…å…¬å¸ã€‚

[J]

Songdoâ€™s backers contend that itâ€™s still early, and business space is filling upâ€”about 70 percent of finished offices are now occupied.

Songdoçš„æ”¯æŒè€…è®¤ä¸ºï¼Œç°åœ¨è¿˜ä¸ºæ—¶è¿‡æ—©ï¼Œå•†ä¸šç©ºé—´æ­£åœ¨å æ»¡çº¦70%çš„å®Œå·¥åŠå…¬å®¤ã€‚

Brent Ryanï¼Œwho teaches urban design at MIT,says Songdo proves a universal principle.

åœ¨éº»çœç†å·¥å­¦é™¢æ•™æˆåŸå¸‚è®¾è®¡çš„å¸ƒä¼¦ç‰¹Â·ç‘å®‰ï¼ˆBrent Ryanï¼‰è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œæ¾å¤šè¯æ˜äº†ä¸€ä¸ªæ™®éçš„åŸåˆ™ã€‚

â€œThere have been a lot of utopian(ä¹Œæ‰˜é‚¦çš„)cities in history. And the reason we don â€˜t know about a lot of them is that they have vanished entirely.â€

â€œæœ‰å¾ˆå¤šä¹Œæ‰˜é‚¦(ä¹Œæ‰˜é‚¦çš„)å†å²ä¸Šçš„åŸå¸‚ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸çŸ¥é“å…¶ä¸­å¾ˆå¤šäººçš„åŸå› æ˜¯ä»–ä»¬å·²ç»å®Œå…¨æ¶ˆå¤±äº†ã€‚â€

In other words, when it comes to citiesâ€”or anything elseâ€”it is hard to predict the future.

æ¢å¥è¯è¯´ï¼Œå½“æ¶‰åŠåˆ°åŸå¸‚æˆ–å…¶ä»–ä»»ä½•äº‹æƒ…æ—¶ï¼Œå¾ˆéš¾é¢„æµ‹æœªæ¥ã€‚

  1. Songdoâ€™s popularity lies more in its quality of life than its business attraction.

    Songdoçš„å—æ¬¢è¿ç¨‹åº¦æ›´å¤šåœ°åœ¨äºå…¶ç”Ÿæ´»è´¨é‡ï¼Œè€Œéå…¶å•†ä¸šå¸å¼•åŠ›ã€‚

  2. The man who conceived Songdo feels disappointed because it has fallen short of his expectations.

    æ€€ä¸Šæ¾å¤šçš„ç”·äººæ„Ÿåˆ°å¤±æœ›ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒæ²¡æœ‰è¾¾åˆ°ä»–çš„æœŸæœ›ã€‚

  3. A scene in a popular South Korean music video was shot in Songdo.

    éŸ©å›½æµè¡ŒéŸ³ä¹è§†é¢‘ä¸­çš„ä¸€å¹•æ˜¯åœ¨æ¾å²›æ‹æ‘„çš„ã€‚

  4. Songdo still lacks the financial stimulus for businesses to set up shop there.

    æ¾å²›ä»ç„¶ç¼ºä¹å¯¹ä¼ä¸šåœ¨é‚£é‡Œå¼€åº—çš„è´¢æ”¿åˆºæ¿€ã€‚

  5. Airplanes will increasingly become the chief means of transportation, according to a professor.

    ä¸€ä½æ•™æˆè¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œé£æœºå°†è¶Šæ¥è¶Šæˆä¸ºä¸»è¦çš„äº¤é€šå·¥å…·ã€‚

  6. Songdo has ended up different from the city it was supposed to be.

    æ¾å²›æœ€ç»ˆä¸åŸæœ¬çš„åŸå¸‚æœ‰æ‰€ä¸åŒã€‚

  7. Some of the people who work in Songdo complain about boredom in the workplace.

    åœ¨æ¾å²›å·¥ä½œçš„ä¸€äº›äººæŠ±æ€¨å·¥ä½œåœºæ‰€çš„æ— èŠã€‚

  8. A business professor says that a future city should have easy access to international transportation.

    ä¸€ä½å•†ä¸šæ•™æˆè¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œæœªæ¥çš„åŸå¸‚åº”è¯¥å¯ä»¥æ–¹ä¾¿åœ°è·å¾—å›½é™…äº¤é€šã€‚

  9. According to an urban design professor, it is difficult for city designers to foresee what will happen in the future.

    æ ¹æ®ä¸€ä½åŸå¸‚è®¾è®¡æ•™æˆçš„è¯´æ³•ï¼ŒåŸå¸‚è®¾è®¡å¸ˆå¾ˆéš¾é¢„è§æœªæ¥ä¼šå‘ç”Ÿä»€ä¹ˆã€‚

  10. Park Yeon Soo, who envisioned Songdo, feels a parental connection with the city.

    æ„æƒ³æ¾å²›çš„æœ´å»¶æ´™ï¼ˆPark Yeon Sooï¼‰æ„Ÿè§‰åˆ°äº†çˆ¶æ¯ä¸è¿™åº§åŸå¸‚çš„è”ç³»ã€‚
